name: Crude palm kernel oil, at plant
description: Industry sources have indicated solvent extraction of palm kernel oil accounts for only a minor portion of the crude palm kernel oil production. Mechanical extraction may be carried out in either a single-or double-press system. Data for this module assumes only one-third of all crude palm kernel oil is produced by way of a double-press system. The remainder was assumed produced from a single-press system.  Cake and pellets are produced as coproducts. Mass partitioning was used to give credit to these coproducts.  Complete inventory data and metadata are available in full in the final report and appendices, Cradle-to-Gate Life Cycle Inventory of Nine Plastic Resins and Four Polyurethane Precursors. This report has been extensively reviewed within Franklin Associates and has undergone partial critical review by ACC Plastics Division members and is available at: www.americanchemistry.com. Quantities may vary slightly between the reference to main source and and this module due to rounding.  Important note: although most of the data in the US LCI database has undergone some sort of review, the database as a whole has not yet undergone a formal validation process.  Please email comments to lci@nrel.gov.

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Mechanical extraction using high-pressure screw pressing, solvent extraction with hexane, or preprocessing followed by solvent extraction
processDocumentation.restrictionsDescription: All information can be accessed by everybody.

exchanges.description: Mass imbalance is due to unavailability of the weight of empty fruit bunches, fiber, and kernel shells sent to incineration.

exchanges.description: Values for ocean freighter transport are calculated based on average fuel consumption rates as determined from a personal communication with Rich Sonnenschein, U.S. Department of Transportation, Maritime Administration in February 2004: 10% of ocean freighters use diesel fuel, 90% use residual fuel, and a freighter that consumes residual fuel consumes 1.9 gallons per 1,000 ton-miles
